reviewText:
In Tin Star, you play a US Marshal, presumably occupied with Honor, Law, and Order (there are stats for each category).  My primary complaint about the game is that it offers too much individual freedom, to the point of departing from its premise.  What kind of Marshal blows up dams, robs wagons and shoots people under no provocation?  While many scenarios have diplomatic solutions, violence isn’t only a last resort.  In other words, I think the story might have been more convincing if the player had other careers to choose from, as opposed to being made a Marshal by default.

That being said, any fan of RPG’s should welcome Tin Star.  It’s constructed like a massive Western D&D campaign and is both one of the longest and most interactive titles by Choice of Games.  The challenges it offers are numerous and inventive, avoiding the grindy repetition typical of the RPG genre.

My Thoughts/About The GameHosted Games did a good job; interactive RPG style novel. Your choices effect how the story goes. Make one bad decision and you must stick with it throughout the story. Most choices don't effect at all, but some are very crucial to the story. Kill that person; bad choice, now everyone thinks you are a terrible person. Now lets get onto the pros and cons.

+ You can be straight/gay
+ Stats to look at
+ Very well written

Cons:
- You can't save the game. Only autosaves
- Parts of the story seems out of place
- You already know the names of the people you'll encounter by checking the stats at the beginning
- When doing your own chores, nothing adds to the story

In Conclusion  Obviously, there are more pros than cons. Tin Star promised me what I would get when I play the game. From beginning to end, I felt like I was always part of the story. I made a bad choice? Now the game makes me feel like ♥♥♥♥. Finally, I recommend this game.

reviewText:
Bought this on a whim. Wasn't sure what to expect, but was very pleasantly surprised.

What you get is an entirely text based, 10 chapter story where you develop your character as a US Marshal in 19th century Nevada. After some introduction, you start each chapter in the hub of your town where you decide what to spend your limited time and very limited money on, and then something happens that needs a Marshal. The mission of each chapter has a nice variety, ranging from quiet investigations to big skirmishes, and the real selling point here is the choice it gives you on how to approach every thing in them. Generally after some investigating things get drastic and you have to make a series of choices based on your skills, knowledge, and character. With about 4 or 5 and sometimes 8 options for every bit, I never felt too pressured to do one thing or another. The amount of 'just shoot them' options make renegade Shepard look like a pacifist.

Behind the all text is a very RPG like skill system measuring your abilities, alignment, and relationships. It never explicitly says that you fail or succeed at something due to these values as well as never explicitly says when they're checked like in Fallout, only when they increased. I liked this, it gave some immersion and made me think about what the Marshal could do, rather than what numbers said he could do. I rolled a Lawful Good persuasion gunslinger and when I did those types of things, they worked, but when I tried to build something or wrestling a bear, I was up a creek.

The story gradually built up, with the connections between the chapters being revealed more towards the end. The final ending I got was a little boring, I really just went up to someone, arrested him, and that was it. I probably could have gotten something more interesting if I decided to do more shooting and less talking, and it didn't help there was a weird period of nothing between big action finale and the actual ending of the story. However you do get a full rundown of how your choices made a difference and the ultimate fate of your town and the cast that does give closure.

Mechanistically, the text engine used is bare bones looking, but works fine. Conversations are in a layout that should be recognizable to anyone whose played Mass Effect but much more concise, and the 'asking for information' prompts differentiable from 'threaten and shoot them in the face'. I wish they gave it an interface little flavor though, sometimes it felt like I was just taking a really exciting customer service survey.  Some say there's some poor grammar, but unless your an English major this probably won't bother you alot, I never noticed. If, for example, you were just bothered by 'alot', it might be an issue.

One note: There is permadeath, but only if you 'accept' the fatal mistake. You lose a cosmetic point at the end of the game, but that's it. Additionally, you can save and reload at the end of chapters. Progess is save automatically.

I got 6 hours out of one playthrough, asking every question possible and restarting a chapter a few times to get a better ending. I'd expect another run would be shorter with reading less background, and probably it would take about 4 playthroughs total to see the outcome of most things major. That's quite a bit of game for $5, if you don't mind reading it.



tl;dr: A very intense customer service survey set in 19th century Nevada about making good choices.

reviewText:
You don't see very many games set in the Old West, so when one comes along, it's a novelty.

Tin Star is a Text Adventure, although not in the same sense as Zork, Moonmist, Planetfall, etc. In those games you actually had to type out commands to interact with the world, whereas Tin Star has pre-defined choices. You often get a bunch of options to choose from, but even so, you're still limited to whatever the author programmed.

In this sense, Tin Star resembles the Choose Your Own Adventure book series, which ran from 1979 to 1998. Anyone who grew up in the 1980s and early 1990s likely spent hours with different CYOA novels. I know I did.

The story of Tin Star follows a man or a woman (you can select your gender, name, and sexual orientation) who was saved from execution via hanging and made the sheriff of a small town. During the game, you get to meet all sorts of individuals, many of whom can be either friend or foe depending on how you interact with them.

Unfortunately, I can't delve too much into the story without ruining it, but I can say that there were a number of plot twists. Unlike some AAA titles that advertise your choices will matter
date:
Tin Star actually makes good on that promise.

There are no graphics, music or sound effects of any kind. This means you'll have to use your imagination to conjure up the imagery, but given that the author provides plenty of information, that's not too difficult.

One minor benefit to a total lack of audio is that you can easily play your own music in the background without it interrupting anything or being interrupted by the game's music/sound effects.

The system requirements are so low that even a PC that's over a decade old could run Tin Star. So if you have an older machine or an underpowered laptop, rest assured you won't have any problems here.

I do have a few issues" with the game
recommended: however.\n\n1. The visuals consist of black text on an off-white background. While that's a fine setup
hoursPlayed: it'd be nice if the player could choose their own text and background colors. I know some people prefer using a dark background and lighter text
voteText: especially if they're playing in a dimly-lit room.\n\n2. As far as I can tell
helpfulPercent: Tin Star only saves your game at the end of each chapter
votesHelpful: and only then if you tell it to do so. This is because you can replay the chapter if you want to try something different
votesFunny: but it also means you have to start that chapter over at the beginning.\n\n3. There's only one save file. If you start a new game
commentsCount: your old save will be written over. So if someone else in your household wants to play Tin Star
column16: make sure you back up your save or that they have their own Steam account and use family sharing.\n\nBottom line: It won't win any awards for being flashy or technologically impressive
column17: but what it does have is a good interactive story with meaningful choices and interesting characters. I'd recommend Tin Star

reviewText: I must say that Tin Star must be one of the most story-rich, narrative driven games that i've ever had the pleasure of playing in recent years. An all without graphics, or sound! That really says something. To tell the truth, i hadn't played an interactive novels before this one, and from now on, i'm comparing every one that i DO play to Tin Star, why? because of the narrative, that's why. In an interactive novel such as this one, especially without graphics or sound, you have to hold the players attention in some way. If you don't, than you've failed a designing the game. However, Tin Star had me hooked all the way from the begining to the end. The writer, Allen Gies has immense talent for writing, and i commend his work. The style in which he delivers each new situation is always engaging, though sometimes feels a bit forced. And with that, let's get into the very few flaws of the game. First of all, the characters. Now, don't get me wrong, I loved the characters in Tin Star. They were very well writen and had diversity, but, their character buildup is very steriotypical. For instance, you've got the stoic cowboy, the renegade gunslinger, the eccentric prospecter, etc. However, like i said before, the way in which they were written makes up for it. The spelling could use some correction, but that's just more nitpicking than anything. And lastly, the ending. The ending feels really forced, and afterwards, you are presented with a lengthey epilouge that tell you what your character did after the ending, instead of letting you play it yourself. I can understand this for the other characters, but for the protagonist, it doesn't make sense to me. One of the negatives to having a simple, white canvas to write a story on is that your eyes start to get annoyed if you look at it for too long. Tin Star has the same problem. When i'm playing a game, i want to be told an engaging and thrilling story. Not be blinded. People with sensetive eyes will not enjoy the experience. I suggest switching to a more eye-freindly backdrop like dark blue, or something. Unfortunatley, ther's no way to change this yourself. And those are really all the negatives. Most of them are really nit-picky things, but negatives nonetheless. Every game has them. All in all, I really reccomend that you try this game. Especially if you want to be told an engaging story with many branching paths. I will definetly be trying more CYOA games, and Zombie Exodus is next!

reviewText:
This is one of Choice of Games' strongest gamebooks so far. I am on my third playthrough and I feel like I've unearthed but a very small part of what the game has to offer. The atmosphere is amazingly well-done, I love how intricate the situations can get, I particularly enjoy the romances. Miss Caraway has a special place in my heart.

If you love interactive novels, you'll love this. No doubt about it. It's well done, it's LONG (longer than most CoG's gamebooks), it's engaging, really the whole package.

If I had a tiny minus: I think that sometimes the game doesn't take into account that you haven't discovered one fact yet. I've had this happen to me once [SPOILER ALERT, don't read further if you haven't played the game yet], the game considered I already knew that Hartigan was Carrie's dad, but in fact, in this specific playthrough, I didn't know about that because I hadn't even met him yet.

Aside from that minor thing, I have zero complaints. I'm a big fan of CoG and this is one of their best work.
